learningObjectives: Click/tap next or swipe left or right to make choices
text: It's your first day at Reel Polytechnic. It's a beautiful day and the sun is shining.
Your friend Beejou finds you and buzzes over. \n\n Hey there! Since you're here early, let me take you on a tour!
Normally, I'd bring you to The Pond for a snack. It's our cafeteria with a real pond, but it's closed right now...
Also, watch out for the geese on campus. They've been extra bothered since they closed The Pond.
You follow Beejou through the campus, learning about the different buildings, facilities, and activities available here.
As you settle in, stay alert for phishing scams. They could be suspicious emails, fake websites, or strange requests.
There's been a lot more recently. The campus IT Security team's worried.. Remember, always verify the source before trusting any information!
As you both explore, you notice the beautiful building, vibrant student life and the various events advertised on the bulletin boards.
Beejou stops suddenly. \n\n Oh wow, we've wandered far! I know a shortcut back. Let's take a bee-tour back to the main building.

learningObjectives: It's decision time! click/tap or swipe left or right to Trust or Distrust
text: Do you trust Beejou to get you back in time?
trustChoice.feedback:
You trust Beejou and follow her shortcut. 

 The path takes you through a lovely garden and you reach the main building quickly. 

 'See? Told you it was a good shortcut!' Beejou beams.
distrustChoice.feedback: You suggest another route back to the main building. \n\n The path takes a bit longer and you're running out of you-time, but you make it to your next lesson with a minute to spare.

text: You're checking your email in between power naps at the campus library.
There's an offer to access a plentitude of ebooks and textbooks!
It sounds like it could be a good deal...
First, you check who's sending this to you.
Then you examine the body of the email.
Finally, look at the offer and the signature.
Should you trust this offer?
trustChoice.feedback:
It's worrying when you crack open the dusty .pdf of 'Key Study Habits for Sucess.' 

 It's just a single paged document listing out 3 study habits: 

 1. Studie with TV on. 2. Pcrorastinate until the last minnit. 3. Skip brekfast.
distrustChoice.feedback: You report it as a phishing attempt and are thanked for your report. \n\n You worry you'll have to find 10,000's of books elsewhere, but you remember you can go to the library!

learningObjectives: If an offer looks too good to be true, it probably is!

text: You're taking a walk around campus enjoying the fresh air when you get a call from Beejou!
(Beejou calls you) I'm planning a weekend getaway with my friends!
We're looking for a cool AirBee & Beaver and found this site with amazing discounts!
She sends you the link.
You take a good look at the website...
Should I go ahead and book it? What do you think?
trustChoice.feedback: After booking, Beejou receives an email saying there's an issue with her payment. \n\n She's starting to wonder if it was a good idea after all...
distrustChoice.feedback: You point out the red flags to Beejou. \n\n She's glad she asked you instead of trying to save some money and she thanks you for your help.

learningObjectives: Inconsistent language, unprofessional layouts, spelling mistakes, and an artificial sense of urgency are all red flags in a phishing scam!

text: You and Beejou are standing outside The Pond, looking into the windows to see if it's almost ready to re-open.
I wanted to ask, have you set up MFA on your account yet?
I think it's pretty cool cause it adds an extra layer of security. \n\n Even if someone gets your password, they still need a second factor to access your account.
You should always check the location before approving any MFA requests and make sure it's really you!
Later, you're working in the library and logging into your student account. \n\n You get an MFA prompt!
Should you approve the login attempt?
trustChoice.feedback: Nice job checking the location! You feel reassured knowing your account is protected with MFA.
distrustChoice.feedback: You hesitate to approve the login attempt, unsure if it's really you. Have you ever really been you?

learningObjectives:
Make sure you're you when responding to MFA requests! \n\n Always check before you tap! If you didn’t attempt to login, deny 
the request!

text: One of the best features of Reel Polytechnic's campus is The Pond cafeteria!
You read all about it in the brochure, so you're excited to experience the Advanced Salad Bar.
But you're dismayed that it's closed for "beautification"!
What does that even mean?
You head to the Reel Polytechnic website.
There's a post about it! Let's read on...
Is this a trusted source for this information?
trustChoice.feedback: Sounds like you'll have to go somewhere else for Advanced Salad options, but the new features sound great.
distrustChoice.feedback: Unfortunately the doors are locked. Looks like you better be looking for refreshments elsewhere. \n\n With features like these, this will take months to complete.

learningObjectives:
Always double-check a website's legtitimacy 
before entering info - don't get caught by scams!

text: You're enjoying your morning outside, daydreaming about your next visit to The Pond when it reopens when Beejou flies by.
(Beejou:) Did you see the posters? We're hosting a Four-Armed Basketball tournament!
We have to go! I used to play, back in the day, you know!
But there's a problem... I tried to get tickets, and my card isn't working!
Can you help me get them? Please, I don't want to miss this!
Beejou sends you the website and you open it up on your phone.
Let's take a look at this webpage
Do you buy the tickets?
trustChoice.feedback: You check out and are promised the hand delivery. \n\n You're advised to stay on campus, otherwise they wont be able to find you, but no one ever arrives.
distrustChoice.feedback: Beejou discovers that you can just get tickets at a table by the gym and she says she'll get you a ticket as thanks since you helped her out.

learningObjectives: Phishing scams often ask for far more information than would be necessary for a normal transaction or information request. Be on the look out!

text: You're sitting out on the grass, sipping your coffee and catching up on some reading when Beejou calls you.
(Beejou: )Guess what! Beeyonce is coming to campus!!
I just got an email from my Beeyonce fan community with an exclusive link to buy tickets before they go on sale to the public!
I'm so excited, but also a little nervous...
It opens a link that asks for my student ID and credit card info. Do you think it's ok?
Take a look at the URL
Next, we're going to look at the webpage.
Should Beejou trust the site?
trustChoice.feedback: You and Beejou get front row tickets. Beejou's so excited, she says she wont sleep for weeks.
distrustChoice.feedback: Sounds worrying so you decide not to go. \n\n But you can't help but wonder if concert will be one of those life changing, world altering one that everyone won't stop talking about for weeks...

learningObjectives:
Always double-check a website's legtitimacy 
before entering info - don't get caught by scams!

text: You're the only one at the lounge this morning. You can't wait until The Pond reopens for morning coffee!
Ah! Oh! I'm so glad you're here!
I just got an email that says Security Team Alpha detected suspicious activity using my student ID!
They're gonna lock my account if I don't verify my identity...That can't be good.
I'm me, the one and only Beejou! Could you watch my things while I go and sort this out?
The first thing we're going to look at is the header.
Next, we're going to look at the email's body.
Finally, we're going to look at the email's call to action and signature.
Is this email legit?
trustChoice.feedback: It asks for 3 different forms of ID!\n\n Beejou heads to the library to scan her cards and you make sure her things don't move an inch while she's gone.
distrustChoice.feedback:
It wants 3 different forms of ID!

 You warn Beejou that this is likely a scam. 

 She's relieved because she actually was acting a little suspicious, but only cause she wanted to surprise you with a fresh donut from Do or Donut.

learningObjectives:
Don't spill your personal info via email or phone without security 
checks like PINs, institutional portals or other protective measures! Always 
double-check who's asking before you share

text: You're holed up in the library, surrounded by books.
Deep into your research for a paper, your open tabs are all important articles, except for your email.
You decide to take a peek, but you didn't expect to see this!
This email looks really important.
Keep reading?
Should you download the fix?
trustChoice.feedback:
You download the fix and crack the window as requested. 

 Your computer starts acting weird... and later you learn a goose was spotted causing a scene in the study lounge. 

 Must be unrelated.
distrustChoice.feedback:
You report the email to IT, who confirms it was a phishing attempt. 

 Your caution pays off!

 IT updates the campus security systems to better detect such phishing attempts in the future, and new locks are installed on the campus windows.

learningObjectives: Be on the look out for urgent, invasive demands to install software on your computer that doesn't come from polytechnic IT!

text: You're working late in the study lounge getting some last minute things done before you go home.
You get an email asking you participate in an official polytechnic survey about student life. \n\n You've gotten three of these this week!
I guess it could be worth it to check out.
Let's start by examining the email's header.
Next up, we'll focus on the email's message.
Finally, let's look at the email's call to action and signature.
Is this email legit?
trustChoice.feedback: You get a sweet $10 campus store gift card. \n\n A follow up email gives you two more to share with your friends, or get two really small mugs.
distrustChoice.feedback: You receive an email thanking you for your vigilance in identifying phishing scams, but remember, phishing emails often request sensitive information, which Reel Polytechnic will never do!

learningObjectives: Some phishing scams can be very sophisticated in their appearance and language. But official polytechnic correspondence will never ask for personal information via email.

text: Your computer's going into red alert mode!!! \n\n There's a flashing software update message for BugBuster Antivirus!
You're unsure whether to trust it.
You call the IT service desk for help and they ask you to meet them at The Pond!
Hey there! Let's see what's going on with your computer.
Ah, yes! They mentioned this critical update on BugBuster's blog.
We reviewed it and send out a Polytechnic-wide alert to update it immediately.
Is this update legit?
trustChoice.feedback: You decide to trust their advice and install the update. You feel secure knowing your system is protected.
distrustChoice.feedback: Sure, it sounds critical, but it can't actually be that critical. It can wait!

learningObjectives: Polytechnic IT notices to update software and security procedures should be acted upon in a timely manner to protect staff and students alike!

text: You're researching at the library and get a frantic text from Beejou.
(Beejou: )AAA DONT CLIKC FOR FREE FLOPWERS!!!
You rush to find Beejou. She looks desperate and worried about her computer.
All I did was click a link to get free flowers and now my computer's locked!
You take Beejou to the IT service team to check over her computer. They're catching phish, but they're happy to help.
(beaver 1:) Oh my, this looks like ransomware!
(beaver 2:) We can try to fix it, but Beejou you need to be careful with suspicious emails.
As they work on Beejou's computer, you receive a notification. It's the same email!
(beaver 2): Since you're already here, let's walk through it together.
Hmm. Now, let's look at the body.
I can see how Beejou was fooled.
What do you think about this offer?
trustChoice.feedback: The beaver nods, "I know flowers are tempting but you should be wary about offers that sound too good to be true. \n\n Also you knew it locked Beejou's computer! Don't let yourself get flower bamboozled."
distrustChoice.feedback: "That's right!" the beaver nods, "If an offer sounds too good to be true, it probably is!"

learningObjectives: Ransomware is a serious threat that could seriously affect your life, along with anyone associated with the polytechnic.

text: You recently read that the Campus Cafe is trying out a new robotic coffee handler.
There's a special right now that uses AI to craft the perfect morning beverage based entirely on your mood! \n\n But, when you get your drink, it doesn't seem like it's actually yours...
You call the IT support team for help. They listen to your problem.
(beaver 1:) Bring it to The Pond and we'll test it for you!
You arrive at The Pond, drink in hand.
(beaver 1:) Let's take a look...
They gather around and slap the water with their tails, looking excited.
You suspect that they just might be angling for a free drink…
trustChoice.feedback: You watch as they all take a little sip each. It's kinda cute, so you don't mind, but now you have to go get a new one. \n\n They thank you for your trouble.
distrustChoice.feedback: They just want to taste your drink!! \n\n Even if it's wrong, you might as well keep it. You've gotta get to the gym before it closes!

text: You find Beejou buzzing with excitement in the library.
(Beejou:) I just got a really cool email!
They're looking for cake taste testers for the re-opening of The Pond!
It's always been my dream to be paid to eat cake!
You ask to take a look at that email...
Hmm... Let's keep reading.
Interesting... What do you tell Beejou?
trustChoice.feedback: Beejou arrives later to the job, only to find an empty room and not a single crumb of cake.
distrustChoice.feedback: Beejou decides to distrust the email after you point out the red flags and reports it to Campus IT. \n\n They send out a warning to all students about the scam.

learningObjectives: Student job scams are a common phishing scheme that aim to extract sensitive information and exploit bad security habits.

text: You're working late into the night in the quiet library.
Only the sound of your focused typing fills the air.
Plip... plop... plip... plop...
You hear a soft pattering on the tiled floor.
You wonder if a window was left open or if something got in...
Do you trust the library is empty and leave your laptop unlocked?
trustChoice.feedback: You leave your laptop unlocked and go check the window. \n\n When you return, you find your laptop screen showing an unfamiliar web page! Someone used your laptop!
distrustChoice.feedback: You lock your laptop and head towards the noise. You find an open vent and close it. \n\n While you're screwing it tight, someone passes by. You're relieved you locked your laptop.

learningObjectives: If you absolutely have to leave your laptop or phone unattended, it's critical you secure it with a password to avoid access while you're away!

text: You're preparing for an exam, surrounded by textbooks, notes, and a rainbow of highlighters.
Beejou: I'm glad I found you! You'll never beelieve it!!
This email says I'm getting the Buzz Worthy Scholar Award for my work!
But isn't it a little suspicious to get emails like this?
Can you take a look at it for me?
First we'll look at the header.
Next we'll look at the body.
Should you tell Beejou to trust or distrust the email?
trustChoice.feedback: Beejou visits the Financial Aid Office and receives her scholarship. She thanks you for helping her make the right choice.
distrustChoice.feedback: Beejou hesitates to claim her scholarship, worried it might be a scam. She might still wonder, years from now if it was all just a dream.

learningObjectives: Review communications for official logos, links to trusted domains, and policies that are consisted with polytechnic security processes.

text: You and Beejou are taking a kickboxing class together.
You're just getting into it when you get a notification on your phone.
Your location shows as: "Spooky" Library
trustChoice.feedback: Wait, you're not at the "spooky" library... are you?
distrustChoice.feedback: Good job! Your kickboxing class is definitely not in some "spooky" library... You'd know!

learningObjectives: MFA authorization can provide clues to the veracity of the request, including location info from your mobile phone!

text: You and Beejou are watching the sunset at the end of a long day on campus.
When you go to log in to your email, you get an alert.
Your location shows as: Outside Reel Polytechnic
trustChoice.feedback: You watch the rest of the sunset, confident you made the right choice.
distrustChoice.feedback: You could've approved it. It was you logging in, after all, but maybe the sun's glare made you hit the wrong button.

learningObjectives: MFA authorization can provide clues to the veracity of the request, including location info from your mobile phone!

text: You're listening to a guest lecture by famous marine biologist Dr. Silliam Billiam on their findings about sea squirrels.
You get an alert on your phone that someone's trying to log in as you.
Your location shows as: Ched's Grocer
trustChoice.feedback: Oh no! You're not at Ched's Grocer! That's halfway across town!
distrustChoice.feedback: You're right! You're on campus, not at Ched's Grocer! Phew.

learningObjectives: MFA authorization can provide clues to the veracity of the request, including location info from your mobile phone!

text: You've been napping all afternoon at the library on campus. You found a nice spot on top of the shelves.
Your phone buzzes with an alert that almost knocks you off your shelf.
Your location shows as: The Library
trustChoice.feedback: Good job! You're definitely in the library, sleeping between Canadian Studies and Cognitive Science.
distrustChoice.feedback: Wait a sec, did that say the library? Whoops!

learningObjectives: MFA authorization can provide clues to the veracity of the request, including location info from your mobile phone!

text: Tonight's the grand re-opening of The Pond! It's finally been beautified! \n\n The pond is sparkling, floaties are in the water, and everyone is enjoying the snacks and drinks.
Great job spotting phishing attempts! Just a few slipped by.
At the end of the party, as everyone's sweeping up, you notice something strange... \n\n There's a goose sweeping some dust into a corner. It seems they used the party to sneak in...
Tonight's the grand re-opening of The Pond! The party is bustling with floaties, snacks, and drinks.
Unfortunately we missed a few phishing attempts... We should stay alert!
You see a goose with, you assume, a stolen credit card. What could they be planning?
Tonight's the grand re-opening of The Pond! The party is bustling, but there's an eerie feeling...
We missed too many phishing attempts! \n\n The geese have taken over!
Unfortunately, the geese run the campus now. \n\n They give themselves straight A's and the cafeteria sells worms and corn (gross).
Tonight's the grand re-opening of The Pond! The party's in full swing. \n\n The cafeteria is buzzing with excitement, and the pond is sparkling.
(Beejou:) The party is a huge success! Everyone's enjoying the snacks and drinks. You did an amazing job spotting those phishing attempts!
Even the geese are behaving, floating peacefully in the pond. It's a perfect day at Reel Polytechnic.
